block.p: ''Taming King Coal'' (editorial, Nov. 25) did not mention several important facts about TXU's proposal to provide additional reliable, affordable and cleaner energy to Texas.
''Taming King Coal'' (editorial, Nov. 25) did not mention several important facts about TXU's proposal to provide additional reliable, affordable and cleaner energy to Texas.
First, you do not note Texas's looming shortfall of reliable electric supply. Without additional electricity generation, Texas is expected to fall below reliable levels by 2008.
TXU's comprehensive plan includes doubling our wind power, greater conservation and energy efficiency, and energy from a diverse fuel portfolio.

Regarding the new, advanced coal technology we intend to use, these plants will be 80 percent cleaner than today's average United States coal plant. We will offset 100 percent of key emissions from the new plants and further reduce emissions from current levels by an additional 20 percent.

You cite I.G.C.C. technology (integrated gasification combined cycle) for coal. We are investing in I.G.C.C. development, but the technology is not yet ready for large-scale commercial operation. Ironically, the Times article you cite in the editorial includes an expert who believes that coal is more attractive at this point.
On carbon dioxide, displacing older, less efficient plants with newer, more efficient ones like those in our proposal makes sense today. We are also developing new technologies for the future.
We are building our new plants carbon capture-ready so that new technologies can be added when viable.
Mike McCall Chairman and Chief Executive TXU Wholesale Dallas, Dec. 1, 2006

Correction: December 13, 2006, Wednesday Because of an editing error, a letter on Monday from Mike McCall, chairman and chief executive of TXU Wholesale in Dallas, responding to a Nov. 25 editorial, ''Taming King Coal,'' included an imprecise sentence. It should have read:
''Ironically, the Times article you cite in the editorial includes an expert who believes that our technology is more attractive at this point.''
